article:
In chemistry, physics, mathematics and related fields, 'file dynamics'
(sometimes called, 'single file dynamics') is the diffusion of N (N â â)
identical Brownian hard spheres in a quasi-one-dimensional channel of length L
(L â â), such that the spheres do not jump one on top of the other, and the
average particle's density is approximately fixed. The most well known
statistical properties of this process is that the mean squared displacement
(MSD) of a particle in the file follows,  \mathrm{MSD}\approx
t^{\frac{1}{2}} , and its probability density function (PDF) is Gaussian
in position with a variance MSD. Harris T. E. (1965) "Diffusion with
'Collisions' between Particles", Journal of Applied Probability, 2 (2), 323-338
Jepsen D. W., J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.), 6 (1965) 405. Lebowitz
J. L., Percus J. K., [http://prola.aps.org/abstract/PR/v155/i1/p122_1 Phys.
Rev., 155 (1967) 122].

Results in files that generalize the basic file include:
* In files with a density law that is not fixed, but decays as a power law with
  an exponent a with the distance from the origin, the particle in the origin
  has a MSD that scales like, MSD\approx t^{\frac{1+a}{2}} , with a
  Gaussian PDF.
* When, in addition, the particles' diffusion coefficients are distributed like
  a power law with exponent Î³ (around the origin), the MSD follows,
  MSD\approx t^{\frac{1-\gamma}{2/(1+a)-\gamma}} , with a Gaussian
  PDF.
* In anomalous files that are renewal, namely, when all particles attempt a jump
  together, yet, with jumping times taken from a distribution that decays as a
  power law with an exponent, â1 â Î±, the MSD scales like the MSD of
  the corresponding normal file, in the power of Î±.
* In anomalous files of independent particles, the MSD is very slow and scales
  like, MSD\approx log^2(t) . Even more exciting, the particles form
  clusters in such files, defining a dynamical phase transition. This depends on
  the anomaly power Î±: the percentage of particles in clusters Î¾ follows, 
  \xi \approx \sqrt{1-\alpha^3} .
* Other generalizations include: when the particles can bypass each other with a
  constant probability upon encounter, an enhanced diffusion is seen. When the particles interact with the channel, a slower diffusion is
  observed. Files in embedded in two-dimensions show similar
  characteristics of files in one dimension.

Generalizations of the basic file are important since these models represent
reality much more accurately than the basic file. Indeed, file dynamics are
used in modeling numerous microscopic processes: MejÂ´Ä±a-Monasterio C.;
Oshanin, G. (2011). "Bias- and bath-mediated pairing of particles driven
through a quiescent medium", Soft Matter, 7 ,993-1000 KÃ¤rger J. and
Ruthven D. M. (1992) Diffusion in Zeolites and Other Microscopic Solids (Wiley,
NY). Wei Q. H., Bechinger C. and Leiderer P.,
[http://www.sciencemag.org/content/287/5453/625.short Science, 287 (2000)
625]. de Gennes J. P., J. Chem. Phys., 55 (1971)
572. Richards P. M., [http://prb.aps.org/abstract/PRB/v16/i4/p1393_1
Phys. Rev. B, 16 (1977) 1393]. Maxfield F. R., Curr. Opin. Cell
Biol., 14 (2002) 483. Biological Membrane Ion Channels: Dynamics,
Structure, And Applications, Chung S-h., Anderson O. S. and Krishnamurthy V.
V., editors (Springer-verlag) 2006. Howard J., Mechanics of Motor
Proteins and the Cytoskeleton (Sinauer associates Inc. Sunderland, MA)
2001. the diffusion within biological and synthetic pores and porous
material, the diffusion along 1D objects, such as in biological roads, the
dynamics of a monomer in a polymer, etc.
